item.title: My First Java
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

Haha, you’re the wrong one cake_. GETSTATIC’s structure is a byte, then an unsigned short denoting the location of a ConstantFieldref describing the desired field in the class’s constant pool. You use CFParse’s eye-pleasing formatting, which is by no means correct. So technically, you’re both simultaneously wrong and right.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Java
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

[quote=“White Castle, post:14, topic:155866”]getstatic java.lang.System.out
bipush 3
invokevirtual java.io.PrintStream.println I

I R the best!!![/quote]
GETSTATIC’s first ‘argument’ is the object type of the file you’re trying to ‘get’, in this case java.io.PrintStream, which, in this case, your pseudo code lacked.
Second, you’re INVOKEVIRTUAL is also messed up. A fixed version would be:

getstatic java.io.PrintStream java.lang.System.out
bipush 3
invokevirtual void java.io.PrintStream.println(int)

Though all in all nice to see someone who actually knows what they talk about.

Read full topic

This I i find alot neater[/quote]

item.title: My First Java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

It works, haha.

Some things you may (not) know:
Intializing variables can be done on one line (int[] anArray = new int[3])
The array only holds two values, so the 3 isn’t necessary, but that’s if you just want to be a stickler about things.

You can add my list to Ollie’s post XD

Read full topic

item.title: My First Java
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

class SumCalculator {
public static void main(String[] args) {
int[] anArray = new int[]{100, 200};
System.out.println(anArray[0] + anArray[1]);
}
}

does the same, but nevertheless, well done

Read full topic

item.title: My First Java
item.dc:creator: @spankjava spank
item.description:
@spankjava wrote:

Well i no its not much but i im reading sum tutorials on swing to make a gui for it

but here it is

[code]
class +SumCalculator {
public static void main(String[] args) {
int[] anArray;

      anArray = new int[3];
        
      anArray[0] = 100;
      anArray[1] = 200;

      System.out.println(anArray[0] + anArray[1]);

 }

} [/code]
